title: Check Division by 4

title: Check Division by 6
description: Check divisibility by 2 and 3.
steps: Rule: Must be divisible by 2 AND 3.
1. Is it even? Yes, ends in 2.
2. Sum of digits: 4 + 3 + 2 = 9. Is 9 divisible by 3? Yes.
Since it passes both tests, it is divisible by 6.
tip: A number must be even AND have a digit sum divisible by 3.

title: Check Division by 8

title: Find Original Price After Discount
description: Calculate the original price before a discount was applied.
steps: Example: A shirt costs $40 after a 20% discount. What was the original price?
If 20% was off, $40 is 80% (100% - 20%) of the original price.
example: $40 after 20% off means original price was $50.
tip: Divide the final price by (1 - discount rate).

title: Chained Percentages (Sequential Discounts)
description: Calculate the effect of multiple percentage changes in a row.
steps: Example: $100 item is 20% off, then an extra 10% off.
tip: This is NOT a 30% discount! (which would be $70). Always calculate one after the other.

title: Multiply by 50

title: Divide by 50

title: Multiply by 125

title: Subtraction by Compensation (Rounding Up)
description: Subtract an easier number, then add back the difference.

title: Multiply Mixed Numbers Near 100

title: Divisibility by 7 (Double and Subtract)
description: A recursive method to check for divisibility by 7.
steps: Subtract it from the rest of the number: 67 - 4 = 63
Is the result divisible by 7? Yes, 63 ÷ 7 = 9.
tip: You can repeat the process if the number is still too large. 343 -> 34 - (3×2) = 28. 28 is divisible by 7.

title: Divisibility by 11 (Alternating Sum)
description: Check divisibility by 11 using an alternating sum of digits.
steps: Start from the right, add and subtract digits alternatingly.
If the result is 0 or divisible by 11, the number is divisible by 11.
tip: This is a fast and powerful check for large numbers.

title: Find Last Digit of a Square
description: Quickly identify if a number *cannot* be a perfect square.
steps: A perfect square can only end in 0, 1, 4, 5, 6, or 9.
If a number ends in 2, 3, 7, or 8, it is NOT a perfect square.
example: Can 123,456,787 be a perfect square? No, it ends in 7.
tip: This is a fast elimination check for square root problems.

title: Find Last Digit of a Cube
description: Finding the last digit of a cube is easy because every digit is unique.
steps: The last digit of the cube root matches the last digit of the cube, with a few pairs.
1³ ends in 1. 4³ ends in 4. 5³ ends in 5. 6³ ends in 6. 9³ ends in 9. 0³ ends in 0.
example: The cube root of a number ending in 7 must end in 3. (e.g., ³√27)
tip: Pairs to memorize: (2,8) and (3,7). All others are themselves.

title: Estimate Cube Roots (The 2-Part Trick)
description: Find the cube root of a perfect cube (up to 6 digits) almost instantly.
steps: 1. Last Digit: Number ends in 6. Only 6³ (216) ends in 6. So, the last digit of the answer is 6.
2. First Digit(s): Ignore the last 3 digits (616). Look at the remaining part: 175.
3. Find where 175 fits: It's between 5³ (125) and 6³ (216).
4. Always take the *smaller* number. The first digit is 5.
tip: This trick feels like magic, but it's pure logic. It works every time for perfect cubes.

title: Percentage Change
description: Calculate the percentage increase or decrease between two numbers.
steps: Formula: (New Value - Old Value) / Old Value * 100
example: From 50 to 60 is a 20% increase. From 60 to 50 is (50-60)/60 = -16.67% decrease.
tip: The 'Old Value' (the starting point) is always the denominator. This is the most common mistake.

4. This is your new guess (g₂ = 3.166). It's already very close!
tip: The formula is (guess + number/guess) / 2. This is the algorithm calculators use!
